{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3357000,"name":"Mithul Balasubramanian","username":"elctrilica","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/elctrilica/{size}/264271_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-09T23:50:39.884Z","cooked":"

I’m a first-year electrical member and while I’m catching onto a lot of the technical parts such as wiring and all that, I would love to learn more about how electrical theory works.

I’m familiar with concepts like current and resistance but I’m confused about why certain things are the way they are. Like why is the current on fuses measured as opposed to voltage? why do certain things need resistors added to them? how are voltage, current, and resistance all relative yet different? these might be some stupid questions but I’d appreciate any information that could deepen my understanding. Feel free to dump all your knowledge upon me.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":33,"updated_at":"2024-04-09T23:50:39.884Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":217,"reads":685,"readers_count":684,"score":1267.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":462007,"topic_slug":"how-does-electrical-theory-work","display_username":"Mithul Balasubramanian","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65551,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"862 Electrical Lead"},"post_url":"/t/how-does-electrical-theory-work/462007/1","custom_user_title":"862 Electrical Lead","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3357006,"name":"Rocky","username":"Rocky_S","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rocky_s/{size}/220194_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-09T23:56:33.909Z","cooked":"

  1. Measuring Current on Fuses: Fuses are designed to protect electrical circuits from overcurrent situations that could lead to damage or fire hazards. Current is the flow of electric charge, typically measured in amperes (amps). Fuses are rated for a specific current limit, and they are designed to break the circuit when the current exceeds this limit. Therefore, measuring the current passing through a fuse is crucial for ensuring that it operates within its designed limits. If the current exceeds the rated value, the fuse will blow, interrupting the circuit and preventing further damage.

  2. Adding Resistors: Resistors are added to circuits for various reasons, including limiting current flow, voltage division, controlling LED brightness, biasing transistors, and matching impedance.

    • Limiting Current: In many cases, resistors are used to limit the current flowing through a circuit component, thus preventing damage caused by excessive current.

    • Voltage Division: Resistors can be used to divide voltage across a circuit, allowing for precise voltage control in different parts of the circuit.

    • Controlling LED Brightness: In LED circuits, resistors are often used to limit the current flowing through the LED, thus controlling its brightness and preventing it from burning out due to excessive current.

  3. Voltage, Current, and Resistance:

    • Voltage (V): Voltage represents the electric potential difference between two points in a circuit and is measured in volts. It is what causes electric charge to flow in a circuit. Voltage can be thought of as the “pressure” that drives electric current through a circuit.

    • Current (I): Current is the flow of electric charge and is measured in amperes (amps). It represents the rate at which electric charge flows through a circuit. Current flows from areas of higher voltage to areas of lower voltage.

    • Resistance (R): Resistance is a property of materials that impedes the flow of electric current. It is measured in ohms (Ω). Resistance determines how much current will flow through a circuit for a given voltage. According to Ohm’s law, the relationship between voltage (V), current (I), and resistance (R) in a circuit is given by V = IR, where V is voltage, I is current, and R is resistance. Thus, voltage, current, and resistance are interrelated through Ohm’s law, but they represent different aspects of the behavior of electric circuits.

Edit: Copied

US Department of Energy has some nice tutorials.

If you find this subject fascinating (I did at your age, and still do now that I am really old), then I think your high school will offer a physics class, and I know your state has several very good universities where physics and electrical engineering are taught.

So from what I understand, voltage isn’t the current that’s flowing but what causes it to flow and amperage measures the rate of the current flowing? Correct me if I’m wrong.

Voltage is electromotive force. In water hose theory. Voltage is the same as pressure. Amps is the same as mass flow or volumemetric or gallons per minute.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":33,"updated_at":"2024-04-10T00:24:15.587Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":380,"readers_count":379,"score":81.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":462007,"topic_slug":"how-does-electrical-theory-work","display_username":"FrankJ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":65551,"username":"elctrilica","name":"Mithul Balasubramanian","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/elctrilica/{size}/264271_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15944,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2974 Robot Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/how-does-electrical-theory-work/462007/7","custom_user_title":"2974 Robot Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3357051,"name":"Mithul Balasubramanian","username":"elctrilica","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/elctrilica/{size}/264271_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-10T00:31:44.992Z","cooked":"

Thanks, that makes more sense. How would resistance come into play here? Adding a resistor to limit current would lower the amperage. How would a resistor affect the voltage?

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":33,"updated_at":"2024-04-10T00:31:44.992Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":360,"readers_count":359,"score":92.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":462007,"topic_slug":"how-does-electrical-theory-work","display_username":"Mithul Balasubramanian","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65551,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"862 Electrical Lead"},"post_url":"/t/how-does-electrical-theory-work/462007/8","custom_user_title":"862 Electrical Lead","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3357061,"name":"Richard Wallace","username":"Richard_Wallace","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/richard_wallace/{size}/110760_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-10T00:34:37.636Z","cooked":"

The voltage at one terminal of the resistor is lower than at the other terminal. We call that difference a voltage drop. It is equal to the product of the current flowing through the resistor, in Amperes, times the electrical resistance, in Ohms.

The above principle is called Ohm’s Law. V = I x R.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":33,"updated_at":"2024-04-10T00:35:16.205Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":342,"readers_count":341,"score":78.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":462007,"topic_slug":"how-does-electrical-theory-work","display_username":"Richard Wallace","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":65551,"username":"elctrilica","name":"Mithul Balasubramanian","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/elctrilica/{size}/264271_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":1549,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"I live for the details."},"post_url":"/t/how-does-electrical-theory-work/462007/9","custom_user_title":"I live for the details.","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3357079,"name":"Mithul Balasubramanian","username":"elctrilica","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/elctrilica/{size}/264271_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-10T00:43:21.820Z","cooked":"

So that would mean a flow of 18 amps with a resistance of 15 ohm equals a voltage of 270 volts. What if a conductor has no resistance while still having a flow of current? would that make the voltage 0? Or is there something more that changes this?

Thanks for the introduction to Ohm’s Law, I’m going to look into it more in the future.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":33,"updated_at":"2024-04-10T00:43:21.820Z","reply_count":5,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":309,"readers_count":308,"score":106.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":462007,"topic_slug":"how-does-electrical-theory-work","display_username":"Mithul Balasubramanian","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":1549,"username":"Richard_Wallace","name":"Richard Wallace","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/richard_wallace/{size}/110760_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65551,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"862 Electrical Lead"},"post_url":"/t/how-does-electrical-theory-work/462007/10","custom_user_title":"862 Electrical Lead","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3357104,"name":"usbcd36","username":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-10T01:04:02.779Z","cooked":"
elctrilica:

What if a conductor has no resistance while still having a flow of current? would that make the voltage 0? Or is there something more that changes this?

Specifically, if a piece of wire (assume a huge one) has current through it, but you poke both ends with your multimeter and measure 0 volts across it, you can assume the resistance of it is low compared to the current through it.

Check out this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X_crwFuPht4

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":33,"updated_at":"2024-04-10T01:04:02.779Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":278,"readers_count":277,"score":65.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":462007,"topic_slug":"how-does-electrical-theory-work","display_username":"usbcd36","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X_crwFuPht4","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":12}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7334,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-does-electrical-theory-work/462007/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3357155,"name":"Richard Wallace","username":"Richard_Wallace","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/richard_wallace/{size}/110760_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-10T02:12:19.660Z","cooked":"
elctrilica:

What if a conductor has no very low resistance while still having a flow of current?

I hope you won’t mind if I change your question just a little, to make it more pertinent to FRC (the topic of this forum).

Let’s take the example of 10 AWG wire that is four feet long. Say two feet of red wire and two feet of black wire, connecting between the power panel and a motor controller. 10 AWG has a resistance of one milliOhm (0.001 Ohm) per foot, so four feet are equivalent to 0.004 Ohm resistance. A very low value, you agree?

Now let’s say that this circuit is conducting 60 Ampere current for a few seconds, which it very well might do during an FRC match. That wouldn’t trip the breaker, but it would cause a voltage drop across the wire of 60 Ampere x 0.004 Ohm = 0.24 Volt (Ohm’s Law in action!) That small voltage drop doen’t seem like much but it will correspond to about 2% less voltage available to the motor controller, compared to what would have been available without the drop. 2% less voltage means a corresponding reduction in the motor’s available power.

Now suppose the resistance of the wire were larger, because someone decided to used 12 AWG wire (as permitted by FRC Rules), which has 0.0016 Ohm per foot. Now the voltage drop is 60% more than it would have been using 10 AWG wire, so with 60 Ampere current draw the voltage available at the motor controller is reduced by 0.35 Volt, resulting in a larger loss of available motor power than we’d have had using 10 AWG wire.

Does it become easier to understand why some teams choose to use motor circuit wiring that is larger than what FRC rules require? That decision will start to look more important if you think about longer runs of wire, compared to the two feet in this example.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":33,"updated_at":"2024-04-10T02:17:07.171Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":252,"readers_count":251,"score":90.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":462007,"topic_slug":"how-does-electrical-theory-work","display_username":"Richard Wallace","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":1549,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"I live for the details."},"post_url":"/t/how-does-electrical-theory-work/462007/12","custom_user_title":"I live for the details.","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3357208,"name":"Mithul Balasubramanian","username":"elctrilica","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/elctrilica/{size}/264271_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-10T02:38:11.462Z","cooked":"

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":33,"updated_at":"2024-04-10T03:18:59.938Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":217,"readers_count":216,"score":123.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":462007,"topic_slug":"how-does-electrical-theory-work","display_username":"sanddrag","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":1082,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-does-electrical-theory-work/462007/14","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5},{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":9,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3357346,"name":null,"username":"veg","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/v/3be4f8/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-10T09:30:33.939Z","cooked":"
elctrilica:

What if a conductor has no resistance while still having a flow of current? would that make the voltage 0?

This is the fundamental question.

According to Ohm’s Law, V = IR. So if you plug zero Ohms into that equation with a non-zero voltage, you get an infinite current. This implies that you cannot have a zero-resistance connection between two points in space, unless they are at the same voltage potential. (Or conversely, if you had a perfect 0-Ohm wire, it would equalize the voltage potential along its entire length.)

When you consider the implications of that, it means every wire has some small resistance. You cannot have voltage or current without resistance.

It can also be helpful to think about the power that is flowing through a circuit. Power (in Watts) is measured as P=VI. So voltage and current are two sides of a square whose area is the power. If you draw more current from the same power source, the voltage will drop so that the total area of the square is unchanged. This is why your battery voltage droops when under a heavy load.

You are asking yourself the right questions. If you haven’t read this before, The Intel Trinity is a really fascinating book about the imperfect personalities that built Intel. It is astonishing to think that a few physics geeks basically invented three different types of transistors over a short period of time, partly as a way to one-up each other.

A strong foundation in physics will take you far.

elctrilica:

What if a conductor has no resistance while still having a flow of current? would that make the voltage 0? Or is there something more that changes this?

What you describe here is known as a short (circuit). This will cause a really high (near infinite) current for a very short amount of time (milliseconds) and is potentially a very dangerous situation.
The opposite of a short is an open (circuit). Think broken, cut, or detached wire. This is much more common, especially in FRC. This would be an infinite resistance and zero current.
An understanding of Ohm’s Law will give you 95% of what you will ever need in FRC.

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":33,"updated_at":"2024-04-10T13:32:23.413Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":18,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":154,"readers_count":153,"score":45.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":462007,"topic_slug":"how-does-electrical-theory-work","display_username":"Mithul Balasubramanian","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":57175,"username":"SolidNotWorks","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/solidnotworks/{size}/208391_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65551,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"862 Electrical Lead"},"post_url":"/t/how-does-electrical-theory-work/462007/19","custom_user_title":"862 Electrical Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3357455,"name":"","username":"SolidNotWorks","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/solidnotworks/{size}/208391_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-10T13:36:32.479Z","cooked":"

The simplest way to explain voltage is it is a “push” force. The picture posted by @sanddrag displays this very well. However, voltage is still affected by raising and lowering current and resistance.

image916×460 5.23 KB

Conceptually: voltage can be generated in many ways. The most common you will see is generators which use magnetism to create voltage. Magnetism and voltage work hand in hand.

If you want to know “why” electrons have the reason to move at all, I would google a certain man named Coulomb. I would not mind explaining it though.
